title: In Partnership with Citi, FGV Promotes Forum on Innovation and Sustainability in the Value Chain at Fecomercio-São Paulo's Expocietec 2012
summary: São Paulo - To mark the close of the 2012 Cycle 2012 of the Innovation and Sustainability in the Value Chain project (ISCV) project, the Sustainability Studies Center at Fundação Getúlio Vargas (GVces), in partnership with Citi and with the sponsorship of the Citi Foundation, will hold a forum on Innovation and Sustainability in the Value Chain on October 16.
tag-1: In Partnership with Citi, FGV Promotes Forum on Innovation and Sustainability in the Value Chain at Fecomercio-São Paulo's Expocietec 2012
tag-3: São Paulo – To mark the close of the 2012 Cycle 2012 of the Innovation and Sustainability in the Value Chain project (ISCV) project, the Sustainability Studies Center at Fundação Getúlio Vargas (GVces), in partnership with Citi and with the sponsorship of the Citi Foundation, will hold a forum on Innovation and Sustainability in the Value Chain on October 16.
tag-4: The forum is part of Expocietec 2012 (http://www.expocietec.com.br/), a fair showcasing innovation and entrepreneurship, at Fecomercio, the São Paulo state chamber of commerce (Rua Doutor Plínio Barreto, 285, Bela Vista, São Paulo). The forum will present good practices in innovative and sustainable product, service and business-model development for SMEs that are part of large corporate value chains in the areas of technology, waste treatment, air and emissions cleaning and treatment, and biodiversity product chains. The forum will be an interactive space for presenting and exchanging ideas, featuring a roundtable discussion with leading experts in the field and the launch of the project's 2013 Cycle.
tag-5: Of the nine cases of innovative and sustainable entrepreneurship to be presented at the forum, six were selected based on 24 criteria established by GVces at the start of the Innovation and Sustainability in the Value Chain (ISCV) project. The other three cases were presented as points of reference at the project's inception last December. The nine cases will be detailed in the publication that will be released at the forum, which will include lessons learned and results of the project's 2012 Cycle.
tag-6: "They [the nine cases] are SMEs with positive experiences in large corporate value chains. We want to share these experiences as ideas for a Brazil that works ('Brasil que dá certo'), where innovation and sustainability go hand in hand," explained Paulo Branco, ISCV's coordinator. "We hope to give more businesses an incentive to take innovation into account in their business plans and do so sustainably and responsibly."
tag-7: Priscilla Cortezze, superintendent for Public Affairs and Sustainability at Citi Brazil, cites two important merits of the projects: raising awareness of sustainable practices in the productive chain and, just as important, spreading this awareness among market actors. "At the end, we'll have a wide network of SMEs communicating with large corporations, exchanging the best ideas from their systems of production."
tag-8: Context The project's decision to focus on SMEs reflects the fact that small and medium-sized operations make up 99 percent of businesses in Brazil. Even those small businesses with the technical knowledge to adapt in response to market demands often lack the financial resources to put innovation into practice. Large corporations that contract smaller businesses play an important role in promoting the development of ideas and practices that combine innovation and sustainability in SMEs' activities and planning. Innovation and Sustainability in the Value Chain (ISCV), therefore, takes an integrated approach on two fronts – large corporations and SMEs – promoting dialogue among businesses and facilitating the development and spread of innovative initiatives.
tag-9: According to the coordinator, Paulo Durval Branco, the project will have positive results for society as a whole in the long term. "We are changing the linear cycle of 'get it-use it-throw it out' to a 'borrow-use-return' mode of production that is sustainable and takes into account the planet's limits," he said. The theme of the 2013 Cycle of the ISCV project, he added, will be "post-consumption."
tag-10: The cases The forum, which launched the Innovation and Sustainability in the Value Chain project on December 15, 2011, presented three cases involving SMEs and large corporations that illustrate the initiative's potential.
tag-11: Ouro Verde Amazônia, an SME in the municipality of Alta Floresta in the state of Mato Grosso, partners wtih Grupo Orsa to explore the production of non-wood products from the Amazon through projects with local communities and sustainable forest management. Terpenoil, in Jundiaí, São Paulo, already supplies big companies such as Whirlpool, Santander and Citi with cleaning products for industrial processes made with the naturally occurring organic element terpene. Located in Cotia, São Paulo, Pack Less invested in the development of a new type of moving pallet made without wood, generating important environmental and business benefits for companies such as Braskem, Votorantim Metais and Cabot do Brasil.
tag-12: Other equally interesting initiatives developed after the 2012 Cycle selection process will also be included in the publication launched at the Innovation and Sustainability in the Value Chain Forum. They include:
tag-17: Traceability and formalization of the productive chain of alpha-bisabolol extracted from the candeia plant
tag-20: Generation of ozone in high concentrations from ambient air, for cleaning
tag-26: Strategic planning (insertion of sustainability in business solutions, innovations, strategies and goals)
tag-29: Cleaning products made with certified-origin, top-quality prime vegetable materials based on life cycle analyses
tag-32: Reducing pollution from fluorescent light fixtures
tag-33: The São Paulo Metro, GM, 3M, Motorola, Ford, Albert Einstein Hospital, Bradesco, Electrolux, Toyota, Banco do Brasil, Bayer

tag-39: GVces The Sustainability Study Center (GVces) was created in 2003 out of the pressing need for companies, their financers, stockholders, leaders, insurers, consultants and auditors to understand, measure and evaluate the risks and opportunities associated with non-financial impact areas such as the environment, corporate social responsibility and corporate governance. Its mission is to contribute to the implementation of sustainable development in many different areas - equity, social justice, ecological balance and economic efficiency - through the study and dissemination of concepts and practices.
tag-40: FGV-EAESP Founded in 1954, the São Paulo School of Business Administration at the Fundação Getulio Vargas (FGV-EAESP) was Latin America's first business school and has a long tradition of training leaders in the areas of business, government and academia. Known as one of the most prestigious academic centers for the study of business and public administration, the school is characterized by its constant development of research and pioneering studies and is at the forefront of applied knowledge, which it disseminates through publications and projects at its various research centers. Several of its programs have been listed recently in national and international rankings. FGV-EAESP is ranked as the Best School of Business in Brazil, with top grades from the Ministry of Education. It is the first institution in Latin America and one of only a few in the world to obtain triple international accreditation for the quality of its instruction from the AACSB, EFMD and AMBA.
